{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3562507,"name":"","username":"Programming5130","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T00:51:10.227Z","cooked":"

Hello we are currently scrambling trying to fix this error after we were running our practice field and coral fell and struck our electrical plate, primarily our Robo Rio. after this hit the driver station started sending errors about CAN IDs not being found and we began to try to search for any unplugged connections. We were unable to find any wiring errors so we then checked the following,

reset robot
reset driver station
reset programming laptop
reset Robo RIO
Re-wired where CAN Bus begins and terminates
Checked REV Hardware Client
Completely swapped Robo RIO

Where we are confused this that our REV Hardware client reports no issues, we also are still able to run some parts of the robot, with the only functions not running is our swerve drive and our elevator. We run a Pigeon 2 gyroscope and the Phoenix tuner is able to connect however the Pigeon does not appear

I have attached screenshots of our Driver Station, REV Hardware Client, and our Phoenix turner. Any help you could give us would be greatly appreciated. We also leave tomorrow afternoon for our second event in Charleston so we are hoping as a last ditch effort we could get some help there.

Phoenix tuner1599×854 26.6 KB

Rev Hardware Client1599×854 149 KB

DS Console1076×835 30.8 KB

With what you’ve done already, I would check to see if the CAN bus is shorted to the frame somewhere, or if one of the CAN lines is open. I would disconnect the RIO end temporarily and use a multimeter to measure between the two lines and between each line and the frame. Between the lines should be 120 ohms without the RIO connected, and from each line to frame should be near infinite.
If only one of CANH or CANL is open somewhere the bus will kinda sorta work but most messages won’t get through. Ditto if it’s shorted to the frame.
Good luck!
